plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to eastern and southern Asia, known for its glossy dark green leaves and large, rose-like flowers that bloom in winter to early spring. Camellias are ornamental favorites for their bright, showy blooms during colder months.
plants.location: East Asia, cultivated globally in temperate regions
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica was the original source of the tea plant; the same genus (Camellia sinensis) is used to make tea.

plants.name: Wattle (Acacia pycnantha)
plants.description: Australia's national floral emblem, this small tree or shrub produces abundant bright yellow fluffy flower clusters. It blooms in late winter through spring, often brightening the Australian landscape in the southern hemisphere's cooler months.
plants.bloomingSeason: July to November (varies regionally) but can bloom into January in northern Australia
plants.funFact: The Golden Wattle's vibrant yellow flowers inspired the colors of the Australian national flag.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A perennial plant native to mountainous regions of Europe, the Christmas Rose blooms in winter. It has white or pinkish flowers that open in the coldest months, symbolizing endurance and hope through winter.
plants.funFact: Despite its name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose but a member of the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae).

plants.name: Clivia miniata
plants.description: A shade-loving evergreen perennial from South Africa, Clivia miniata blooms in mid to late winter with vibrant orange to red trumpet-shaped flowers. It is a popular houseplant that flowers indoors during the northern hemisphere‚Äôs winter months.
plants.location: South Africa, also cultivated worldwide as a houseplant
plants.funFact: Clivia miniata's flowers are pollinated mainly by sunbirds in its native South African habitat.
